这是他发表过的最重要的演讲，但却没有给人留下深刻的印象。 11 月 3 日，真主党领导人哈桑·纳斯鲁拉发表近一个月前加沙战争爆发以来的首次讲话。他的激进组织几乎从一开始就参与其中，向以色列北部发射了数十枚火箭，最近还发射了载有爆炸物的无人机。它警告说，如果以色列继续对加沙进行地面入侵，战斗将会升级（纳斯鲁拉发表讲话前一周以色列就这样做了）。

阅读我们对以色列和哈马斯之间战争的所有报道

在他发表讲话之前的几天，黎巴嫩局势紧张。支持者发布了纳斯拉拉先生的一系列华丽视频，这些视频的目的是看起来不祥——尽管其美学与其说是宣战，不如说是漫威新电影的预告片。一些黎巴嫩人储备了食物和燃料；其他人收拾好行李，以防需要赶去机场。黎巴嫩是否发动战争将由一个人来决定，而这个人在政府中没有正式职位。总理纳吉布·米卡提承认，这个决定不在他的掌控之中。

但最终，讲话表明真主党仍然希望避免全面战争。纳斯鲁拉先生一脸疲惫地讲话了近 90 分钟。他针对以色列及其盟友美国发表了许多夸大的言论，但没有说出任何暗示局势即将大幅升级的言论。 “这篇演讲本来可以是一封电子邮件，”一位黎巴嫩观众开玩笑说。

相反，纳斯鲁拉先生传达了三个明确的信息。首先，他事先并不了解控制加沙的激进组织哈马斯于 10 月 7 日发生的大屠杀，该组织杀害了 1,400 多名以色列人，引发了战争。纳斯鲁拉称这次袭击“100%是巴勒斯坦人”，并表示此次袭击对真主党、其他巴勒斯坦派别及其共同赞助人伊朗保密。美国、伊朗和以色列的官员都同意这一评估。

第二个是呼吁加沙停火，并敦促其他人实现这一目标。例如，他要求阿拉伯和穆斯林国家对以色列实施石油和天然气禁运，呼应伊朗最高领导人阿里·哈梅内伊几天前的呼吁。这种言论无疑是为了让阿拉伯领导人的无所作为感到尴尬。这也是为了推卸责任：真主党不负责结束战争。

第三个是拍拍自己的背。纳斯鲁拉表示，以色列现在正遭受来自四面八方的炮火——来自加沙的哈马斯、黎巴嫩的真主党以及其他地方伊朗支持的民兵组织——他称这种情况是自 1948 年以色列建国以来前所未有的。然后他列出了以色列军队的名单已部署到黎巴嫩边境。这意味着真主党对以色列的有限火力已经束缚了部分以色列军队，为战争做出了重大贡献。

他接着说，“我们今天的努力不会是终点，而且还不够”。但他保留了自己的选择余地，以应对可能引发局势进一步升级的情况。以色列已经杀害了 9000 多名巴勒斯坦人，造成 150 万人流离失所，并派遣地面部队包围了加沙北部，但没有引起重大反应。

总而言之，他的讲话表明他目前将维持现状。他这样做有几个理由。一是美国派出两支航母编队前往地中海东部，并明确警告真主党不要升级。另一个国家是伊朗，它认为真主党是一种末日装置——一种阻止以色列直接攻击伊朗的强大武器。它似乎不愿意冒着使用武器的风险来拯救哈马斯。

球队在国内也面临着压力。黎巴嫩陷入严重的经济危机已经四年了。年通胀率连续三年超过100%，货币贬值98%。战争会造成该国无法修复的灾难性损害。 2006年，海湾国家承诺提供超过10亿美元用于战后重建，但厌倦了黎巴嫩长期的功能失调和腐败以及真主党对政治的束缚。这次他们不会倾向于慷慨。

同情真主党的报纸al-Akhbar发表的一项民意调查发现，68% 的黎巴嫩人不支持与以色列全面战争。即使在真主党的主要支持者黎巴嫩什叶派中，意见也褒贬不一：51%的人支持战争，49%的人反对战争。

真主党可能希望将其军事克制转化为政治利益。自 2022 年 10 月米歇尔·奥恩结束六年任期以来，黎巴嫩就没有出现过总统。议会已经十多次未能选出继任者。真主党希望建立一个盟友苏莱曼·弗兰吉（Suleiman Frangieh），他是一位政治家，与叙利亚独裁者巴沙尔·阿萨德（Bashar al-Assad）关系密切。该组织可能认为，避免战争将使其能够获得总统职位，或许还有其他职位，例如自三月份以来一直空缺的情报局长职位。

纳斯鲁拉先生讲话时出现了超现实的分屏：美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯正在以色列会见以色列总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡及其战时内阁。他想再次就以色列对加沙的战后计划施压，但该计划仍然含糊不清。但他更紧迫的担忧是该地区恶劣的人道主义状况。

乔·拜登继续拒绝停火谈判，但美国总统已开始推动短暂的停火，以允许更多人道主义援助进入加沙。 “我认为我们需要暂停一下，”他在 11 月 1 日说道。一些以色列军官愿意考虑这个想法——尽管这种暂停可能一次只会持续几个小时。

暂停并不能阻止真主党每天的轰炸。以色列不愿意考虑停火。战争将会持续下去，这不会是黎巴嫩紧张的观众最后一次等待纳斯鲁拉先生宣布他们国家的命运。 ■

乔治·奥威尔 (George Orwell) 在 1940 年写道： “ LL 艺术就是宣传，但并非所有宣传都是艺术。”很少有人会反对这句格言的第二部分。 《我的奋斗》中可怕的胡言乱语毫无艺术可言。但只有当你使用广义的宣传定义时，第一个似乎才是正确的。如今，伟大的艺术作品很少是为了服务政府的目的。他们可能会促进事业，但这通常不是人们尊重他们的原因。然而，这份清单上的书部分证明了奥威尔主张的第一部分。政府或意识形态团体要么鼓励作者写作，要么出于政治目的宣传他们的作品。冷战期间，西方情报机构资助作家，有时甚至是非常好的作家。中央情报局在法国、日本和非洲开设了文学杂志。目的之一是对抗独裁者的审查制度。另一个目标是让全球文化对西方目标更加友好。英国情报部门委托创作了支持帝国的小说作品。一些作家自觉地将笔捐给国家；其他人没有意识到政府或团体会促进他们的工作。这里有六本书，全都是优秀作者的作品，从某种程度上来说都是宣传作品。

亚洲之眼。作者：拉迪亚德·吉卜林。喀什楼； 128页； 13.95 美元和 10 英镑

拉迪亚德·吉卜林作为大英帝国宣传者的角色经常被遗忘。英国情报部门在第一次世界大战期间招募了这位作家，撰写旨在破坏印度民族主义的小说。 1916 年，英国官员詹姆斯·邓洛普·史密斯 (James Dunlop Smith) 向吉卜林发送了在法国作战的印度士兵的私人信件。史密斯要求吉卜林重写它们，以消除任何亲印度或革命情绪。美国杂志《周六晚报》在 1917 年 5 月至 6 月期间出版了四篇文章。（其中三篇出现在《伦敦晨报》上。） 吉卜林只是在将它们整理成一本书《亚洲之眼》时才以自己的名字命名的。作者告诉邓洛普·史密斯，在重写这些信件时，他“在某种程度上放大了[他]认为[他]在信件背后看到的精神”。事实上，他的修改比这更具创造性。在将士兵们的书信变成小说的过程中，他对它们进行了净化。他删除了诸如“我们就像绑在屠夫木桩上的山羊”这样的抱怨，并插入了对英国充满“镀金家具、大理石、丝绸、镜子”的钦佩描述。英国情报部门喜欢它所读到的内容。吉卜林问邓洛普·史密斯是否发现“角色中的种姓或精神面貌存在错误”。看来他没有。许多读者都钦佩一位评论家（撰写小说《金》）所说的吉卜林对印度人民的“积极、详细和非刻板印象”。他作为宣传员的角色蒙蔽了他的视野。

日瓦戈医生。作者：鲍里斯·帕斯捷尔纳克。 复古出版； 512 页； 20 美元和 9.99 英镑

冷战期间，中央情报局试图通过秘密促进书籍和杂志的流通来破坏苏联的审查制度。窥探者送来了陀思妥耶夫斯基、 列夫·托尔斯泰和弗拉基米尔·纳博科夫的小说。他们最喜欢的作家是鲍里斯·帕斯捷尔纳克。中央情报局1958 年的一份备忘录宣称，他的小说《日瓦戈医生》具有“巨大的宣传价值”。对于一个爱情故事来说，这似乎是一个令人惊讶的事情。但中央情报局感兴趣的不仅是这部小说的“发人深省的本质”，还有“其出版的环境”。苏联文学杂志和出版社压制了这本书。其中一位引用了帕斯捷尔纳克对社会主义的“恶毒”和“不接受”。苏联人不喜欢他的宗教热情。一名意大利文学天才星探将《日瓦戈医生》的手稿走私到意大利，并于 1957 年在那里出版。中央情报局发现了一个“机会，让苏联公民怀疑他们的政府出了什么问题，当时该男子的一部优秀文学作品承认成为当今最伟大的俄罗斯作家甚至在他自己的国家也是不可能的”。间谍机构帮助出版了这本书的俄语版。它在东欧代理商的帮助下发行了1000多册，并在1958年比利时世界博览会上分发。它希望俄文原版的出版能为帕斯捷尔纳克赢得诺贝尔奖铺平道路。他这样做了，但苏联人强迫他拒绝。 1965 年，他没能活到看到《日瓦戈医生》成为一部卖座电影（剧照如上图）。

游击队。作者：彼得·马蒂森。复古书籍； 184 页； 5.95 美元和 4.00 英镑

1947 年成立时，中央情报局聘请了许多耶鲁大学的高年级学生。彼得·马蒂森就是其中之一。中情局派他去巴黎，他在那里用自己正在写一本小说作为掩护，但他在该市的中央情报局官员认为这个故事“软弱无力”。马蒂森确实在巴黎写了一本小说，实际上是两本。他的第二部作品《游击队》讲述了美国通讯社驻巴黎记者巴尼·桑德的故事，他追踪了一位希望采访的法国共产党前领导人。当桑德还是个孩子的时候，共产党人就帮助他逃离了西班牙内战。这部小说展示了对该党运作的详细了解，以至于《芝加哥论坛报》在一篇评论中建议作者回到莫斯科。但它显然对西方表示同情。桑德认为共产党人是自私且不诚实的。他的爱国主义精神日益增强。 《游击队》所写的自觉的文学散文预示着马蒂森职业生涯的下一步。他创办了文学杂志《巴黎评论》 ，并以此为幌子监视移居巴黎的美国左翼艺术家和知识分子。中央情报局认为这对他的间谍活动来说是一个更好的掩护。 《游击队》并不是马蒂森最好的作品。他是唯一一位同时获得美国国家图书奖小说和非小说类奖项的作家。但是，当桑德在巴黎蜿蜒而行时，他提醒读者，马蒂森观察他的左派朋友不仅仅是为了艺术。

在德黑兰读《洛丽塔》：书中的回忆录。作者：阿扎尔·纳菲西。兰登书屋； 356 页； 18 美元。企鹅; 9.99 英镑

伊朗移民兼英语教授阿扎尔·纳菲西 (Azar Nafisi) 于 2003 年出版了有关伊斯兰革命的回忆录，一举成名。 《在德黑兰读洛丽塔》在美国一炮而红，在《纽约时报》畅销书排行榜上停留了 117 周。这是八名伊朗妇女秘密聚会学习纳博科夫、古斯塔夫·福楼拜和亨利·詹姆斯小说的引人入胜的故事。纳菲西女士的学生是伊​​斯兰共和国的孩子，他们反抗该国的图书禁令和其“腐败和欺骗性的夸张”言论。这种描述并不适用于《读洛丽塔》，它值得得到的钦佩。然而，它所欠的机构并非典型的文学回忆录。纳菲西女士感谢史密斯理查森基金会提供的资助帮助她撰写这本书，该基金会致力于“促进美国在海外的利益和价值观”。纳菲西女士写道，只有通过“文学，人们才能设身处地为他人着想”。对于西方读者来说，《读洛丽塔》对于她的学生来说就像文学对于她的学生一样具有启发性。它还支持对伊朗神权政治的严厉判断，美国继续希望这种判断能够发挥影响力。

一百年的孤独。作者：加布里埃尔·加西亚·马尔克斯。格雷戈里·拉巴萨译。企鹅; 432 页； 17.99 美元和 9.99 英镑

美国禁止加夫列尔·加西亚·马尔克斯入境三十年，因为他在 20 世纪 50 年代与哥伦比亚共产党有牵连。他曾短暂地加入过一个党组织。然而，由中央情报局资助的哥伦比亚杂志《Mundo Nuevo》在 1967 年该书出版前一年印刷了他的杰作《一百年的孤独》的两章。这些摘录并不包括该书对哥伦比亚“香蕉大屠杀”的描述。 1928年，哥伦比亚军队在美国的压力下对联合水果公司罢工的员工采取行动，杀死了1000多人。 《新世界》印刷的内容是对哥伦比亚的描述，其风格后来被称为魔幻现实主义。该杂志主要发表亲美和反共的文章，这表明它也对政治左派追随者撰写的文章持开放态度。一名中央情报局特工称这种做法为“ fidelismo sin Fidel ”，即古巴统治者菲德尔·卡斯特罗的共产主义信条，但没有反美革命主义。加西亚·马尔克斯发现《新世界》收受中央情报局的贿赂后非常愤怒。在给编辑罗德里格斯·莫内加尔的一封信中，他写道，他感觉自己像个戴绿帽子的人。

月亮落下。作者：约翰·斯坦贝克。企鹅; 144 页； 12 美元和 9.99 英镑

1940 年 6 月，法国与德国签署停战协定两天后，约翰·斯坦贝克写信给美国总统富兰克林·罗斯福，敦促他的政府开展“立即、受控、深思熟虑”的宣传。斯坦贝克采纳了自己的建议，写了一个故事来激励被占领的欧洲人民起来反抗纳粹。 《月亮落下》的故事发生在一个被法西斯势力入侵的无名欧洲国家。斯坦贝克写道，这个虚构的地方的特点是挪威的严厉、丹麦的狡猾和法国的理性。兰瑟上校领导的占领者奋力镇压起义。抵抗纳粹的成员翻译了这本小说并将其偷运到挪威、丹麦和法国。 1945 年，战争结束后，挪威国王授予斯坦贝克国家自由十字勋章，以表彰他对欧洲抵抗运动的贡献。

也尝试一下

我们的宣传报道包括一个互动专题，介绍俄罗斯人民如何看待乌克兰战争。我们的姊妹杂志《1843》带领读者走进莫斯科一间潮湿的教室， 俄罗斯国家电视台的记者在那里接受培训。我们关于习近平的播客“王子”探讨了歌颂中国国家主席的宣传以及理解真实人物的挑战。 在这里，我们写下中国在海外宣传取得的惊人成功。阅读我们对朝鲜首席宣传官金与正的简介。 以下是我们推荐的解释智力如何运作的书籍。 ■

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 20:25:43 GMT /内容/ii7nf081ku2cksvu05jlo1tt64ufsj91 https://www.economist.com/the-economist-reads/2023/11/03/six-books-you-didnt-know-were-propaganda A new Museum of Prohibited Art shows how censorship evolved

克里斯特在战斗机上被钉死在十字架上。麦当劳叔叔被钉在十字架上。传统造型的麦当娜，将手伸到长袍下面的两腿之间。在巴塞罗那新的禁止艺术博物馆，不难发现一个共同的主题。

博物馆中的许多物品都以宗教为主题，但并非全部。对大男子主义政客的嘲笑也有办法引发审查。这是安迪·沃霍尔笔下的毛泽东，还有埃米利亚诺·萨帕塔赤身裸体骑在马背上、戴着粉色宽边帽和高跟鞋的画作。 （这位墨西哥革命领袖的后代荒谬地威胁要起诉艺术家法比安·查雷兹（Fabián Cháirez）诽谤。）博物馆的主要标准是作品受到某种形式的禁止或审查。塔特索·贝内特 (Tatxo Benet) 是一名记者出身的商人，他创办了博物馆并收藏了艺术品。

涉及伊斯兰教的艺术品往往比针对基督教的艺术品更为克制。满屋子的祈祷垫上都打了孔，上面放着一双高跟鞋，由阿尔及利亚裔艺术家祖利卡·布阿卜德拉 (Zoulikha Bouabdellah) 设计。在摩洛哥艺术家阿米娜·本布什塔 (Amina Benbouchta) 的《Piège à loup》中，绣花枕头上放置了一个狼夹。两者都是对伊斯兰社会女性地位的优雅评论，但其震撼价值很难与圣母玛利亚取悦自己相比。

这是因为艺术的风险总是取决于背景。 《鲨鱼》中的萨达姆·侯赛因几乎赤身裸体，被捆绑在甲醛中，水平排列，就像英国艺术家达明·赫斯特（Damien Hirst）类似作品中的真实鲨鱼一样。 2006年，由于丹麦报纸上出现的先知穆罕默德漫画引发暴力，一些欧洲国家的官员出于恐惧而拒绝展示该作品。也许正是因为这个原因，博物馆里没有出现任何描绘先知的作品，尽管博物馆的一位代表表示未来可能会展示一幅。

事实上，博物馆的最强点之一是强调审查制度本身的性质。最粗暴的版本是直接的国家禁令：警察从墙上撕下艺术品并将其锁起来。但有些作品受到个人攻击。例如，自慰的麦当娜画作在 2019 年的一次展览中遭到破坏，至今仍留有刀痕。而且博物馆里的很多作品都经过了艺术家自己的审查。例如，弗朗西斯科·戈雅（Francisco Goya）担心西班牙宗教裁判所不受欢迎的关注，撤回了他的恶毒讽刺版画《随想曲》（Caprichos）的销售。

有时公司和机构会压制言论自由。乐高“拒绝”向中国持不同政见艺术家艾未未发送大量积木订单，称其避免支持具有政治议程的项目。相反，艾未未从支持者那里采购了砖块，战胜了企业的谨慎态度。查克·克洛斯 (Chuck Close) 的自画像是展出的现代取消文化的唯一例子——2017 年，几位女性指控他性骚扰，华盛顿国家美术馆随后取消了他的作品回顾展。

博物馆大厅里矗立着一座佛朗哥秘密警察的雕塑。但参观者离开时会评论说如今的审查制度变得更加微妙。 ■

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 19:04:00 GMT /内容/pljd7hhmar2c2he7tmfehnpc0h75uuls https://www.economist.com/culture/2023/11/03/a-new-museum-of-prohibited-art-shows-how-censorship-evolved The business of mining literary estates is booming

拜伦勋爵打算出版他的回忆录，但他的文学遗嘱执行人却把它烧毁了。人们认为 TS 艾略特从来不想创作有关他的猫的歌曲。英国奇幻作家特里·普拉切特（Terry Pratchett）富有想象力：他的前助手实现了普拉切特的愿望，用压路机压碎装有作者未完成故事的硬盘。

罗尔德·达尔（Roald Dahl）是黑暗而令人愉快的儿童故事的作者，如果他知道编剧会召唤出一个十几岁的威利·旺卡（Willy Wonka），他可能会做出同样激烈的事情。达尔于 1990 年去世，他对根据他的《查理和巧克力工厂》拍摄的第一部电影感到厌恶。很难想象他会为将于 12 月上映的前传《旺卡》欢呼。影片中，蒂莫西·查拉梅（Timothée Chalamet）（如图）饰演的年轻威利对抗巧克力卡特尔。

长期以来，作者们一直试图控制自己死后作品的处理方式，但大多都失败了。然而，达尔的遗产代表了故事的新转折。 2021 年，流媒体服务公司 Netflix 为他的遗产支付了巨额费用，刺激了开采已故作家遗产的淘金热。曾经，最让作家们担心的是史努比传记作家的入侵。如今，继承者们面临着将每一丝创意成果货币化的诱惑。

对流媒体服务和电影工作室新内容的强烈渴望推动了人们对旧书的新兴趣。精明的视频制作人在面对热门新书的竞购战时，转向了更实惠的选择：几十年前写的小说。这些“重新列入”作品的权利通常属于作者去世后 70 年内的遗产。此后，该作品进入公共领域，遗产机构不能再从中获利或控制它。想想今年上映的电影《小熊维尼：血与蜜》，AA米尔恩笔下的小熊维尼和小猪小猪，可爱的、近百岁的角色，变成了嗜血的杀手。

受版权保护的作品进行技术改造的时机已经成熟。他们可以通过多种方式榨取利润，包括出售新语言的翻译权、允许在世作家创作“续篇小说”以及制作流媒体连续剧。例如，Netflix 上最出名的节目《皇后弃兵》实际上是根据 1983 年出版的小说改编的。

传统上，管理作者遗产的知识产权是一件低调的事情，留给侄孙和忙碌的前经纪人。更积极地利用权利的现代时代始于 15 年前，当时美国和英国的明星特工开始争夺伊恩·弗莱明、伊芙琳·沃和弗拉基米尔·纳博科夫的遗产。与此同时，阿加莎·克里斯蒂和达尔的继承人成立了公司来监督不断发展的帝国。

当达尔的孙子（罗尔德·达尔故事公司的经营者）以大约 7 亿美元的价格将作家的目录卖给 Netflix 时，沉睡的文学界意识到了旧作品的商业潜力。 （这是与华纳兄弟达成的一项单独协议的补充，华纳兄弟获得了制作《旺卡》的权利。）重新构思了韦斯·安德森的《亨利·休格的奇妙故事》和其他三个达尔故事，电影制作人，9 月加入 Netflix；新西兰导演塔伊卡·维迪蒂 (Taika Waititi) 计划拍摄两部关于奥姆帕-伦帕斯 (Oompa-Loompas) 和其他达尔角色的连续剧。

即使达尔的作品没有获得轰动一时的待遇，随着旧的印刷品被包装成新的格式，遗产也可以证明是有利可图的。有声读物正在蓬勃发展；据行业组织音频出版商协会称，近年来美国的销量每年至少增长 10%，到 2021 年将飙升 25%。主要图书出版商最近宣布与流媒体服务 Spotify 达成协议，提供有声读物订阅服务。新的格式可以帮助作者的财产产生新的版税。

不过，最大的一笔钱是在屏幕改编上。到 2030 年，全球视频流媒体市场预计将超过 4000 亿美元。根据 Publishers Marketplace 的数据，2020 年改编成电视剧的书籍数量首次超过电影。关于间谍、侦探和儿童角色的故事是节目的自然主题。它们是“黄金品牌”，作家协会主席尼古拉·所罗门 (Nicola Solomon) 解释道，该协会担任 58 名会员遗产的受托人。 “无论好坏，我们生活在一个品牌驱动的世界，人们购买熟悉的品牌，”她补充道。

这笔财富催生了一位强大的新玩家。 2019 年，一个由律师、代理人和电视推广商组成的财团，名为国际文学财产公司 ( ILP )，在纽约和伦敦设立了办事处，大规模开展这项工作。 “过去有很多精彩但未被欣赏的小说，”阿加莎克里斯蒂有限公司前首席执行官、 ILP联合创始人希拉里·斯特朗 (Hilary Strong) 说道。 “我们正在努力做的就是开放它们，并将它们带回来让新一代人理解。”

在私募股权的支持下， ILP已收购了约 50 个文学庄园的部分或全部。它的作品集现在包括兰斯顿·休斯、萨默塞特·毛姆和乔治·西默农等经典作家的作品。 2021 年，该公司出售了一部以西默农饰演的巴黎警察督察儒勒·梅格雷为主角的电视剧的版权。有 84 部梅格雷小说可供选择，不需要侦探就能推断出这可能是一部长期上演的剧。

一些继承人对企业对知识产权的新兴趣感到困惑。实际上，文学遗产是一种新的资产类别。如果管理得当，他们可以提供稳定的收入。所罗门女士表示，就像科技初创公司一样，有些公司拥有“突然爆发的潜力”。

但许多继承人和遗嘱执行人很高兴为他们祖先的作品找到新的读者。以非裔美国科幻小说先驱奥克塔维亚·巴特勒 (Octavia Butler) 的小说为例，她获奖无数，但商业上却鲜有成功，于 2006 年去世。她的遗产在她的前经纪人的领导下授权了新版本，这反过来又将已故作家推上了畅销书排行榜。新的图画小说已经出版，两部电视节目正在制作中，其中包括由美国女演员维奥拉·戴维斯主演的《野生种子》。

严重问题

然而，复兴旧故事会带来风险和棘手的问题。是否可以将老故事换上新包装来迎合当代人的口味？对于种族主义或性别歧视的描述，执行者应该采取什么措施？ “更新”文本的尝试很容易失败。想想当苏斯博士遗产委员会因作者的种族成见而决定在 2021 年撤回某些书名时，人们对“审查制度”的呼喊就知道了。最具争议性的是清理带有攻击性词语的旧书的决定，正如企鹅兰登书屋的编辑今年早些时候对达尔的一系列儿童读物所做的那样，这些书都经过了“敏感读者”的审查。

国际笔会是一个作家倡导组织，在最近一份措辞严厉的报告中写道，“阅读旧书的部分用处在于批判性地评估他们的态度和论点。经典书籍出版后更改其文本，从某种意义上说，就是修改历史。”管理欧内斯特·海明威庄园 20 多年的作家迈克尔·卡塔基斯 (Michael Katakis) 对此表示同意。 “过去的话语是我们去过哪里以及我们从哪里出发的路标，它是我们确定我们是否有所进步或是否还没有走得太远的方式。”

其中最棘手的是所谓的“续篇小说”，例如《朱莉娅》，这是最近从女权主义角度对乔治·奥威尔的《1984》进行精彩重述的作品。可能接受另一种媒介对经典作品进行新处理的传统主义者常常会对那些似乎改变了一位伟大作家的智力遗产的书籍感到愤怒。

但争议对于销售来说并不是坏事。就像达尔心爱的角色查理·巴克特渴望进入旺卡的神秘工厂一样，没有什么可以阻止投资者和电影制片厂继续筛选过往的目录，寻找一张金票。 ■

据传说，第一次马拉松比赛让人筋疲力尽，以至于希腊信使费迪皮德斯（Pheidippides）崩溃了，他从马拉松战场跑了 25 多英里（40 多公里）到雅典，带来了战胜波斯人的消息。然后死了。在接下来的 2500 年里，人类跑这个距离的能力变得越来越好。有些人甚至选择打扮成犀牛。现在，最好的选手在两个多小时内完成了现代马拉松比赛，全程 26.219 英里。 （菲迪皮兹的时间没有被记录。）

在过去的五年里，最好的成绩已经有了显着的提高——毫无疑问，11 月 5 日的纽约市马拉松赛上也会出现更多同样的成绩。这在很大程度上可以通过新一代超弹力跑鞋（“超级鞋”）的开发来解释，它为运动员提供了更大的帮助。这种进步使得一些人质疑该技术现在是否过于主导，因此是否应该从记录中删除最近出现的快速时间过剩现象。这种技术恐惧症是错误的。

令人眼花缭乱的马拉松时间的最新例子发生在柏林和芝加哥的平坦道路上。在德国，埃塞俄比亚选手蒂格斯特·阿塞法(Tigst Assefa)跑出了2小时11分53秒，比现有的女子纪录快了两分多钟。自 2022 年初以来，女子马拉松历史上 10 个最快成绩中有 8 个被记录下来。随后，在风城，肯尼亚选手凯尔文·基普图姆 (Kelvin Kiptum) 以 2:00:35 冲线，将男子马拉松成绩降低了 34 秒。 （图为基普图姆先生获胜后的双脚。） 23 岁的小伙子——顶级马拉松运动员通常年龄较大——基普图姆先生可能会成为第一个打破两小时大关的人。即使他做不到这一点，他的同时代人也会做到。有史以来最快的十名男子成绩中有六项是在过去两年内记录的。

There is little doubt that this generation of athletes are breaking records because of their footwear. Both Nike and Adidas have persuaded the governing body, World Athletics, to permit shoes with chunky, foam soles. These act as springs. When their feet compress the super-shoes into the ground, the runners receive more energy as they push off again than they would with regular shoes. In 2017 Nike announced that the new technology allowed athletes in super-shoes to use 4% less energy than they would if wearing a regular shoe.

Those who would like the shoes banned worry that the balance between the runners' ability and the kit they wear has become skewed. (A lesser concern is that records become less comparable with times from previous eras. But unless today's runners race in ancient clodhoppers, that will always be the case.) Plainly, though, this is a long way from shoes that matter more than runners. A club runner may set a personal best in a pair of Nike Alphaflys, but she is not going to outrun Ms Assefa shod in regular running shoes. World Athletics, the sport's governing body, insists that all such super-shoes should be available to all athletes in order to be legal, so there is no risk of results being determined by a lack of access to the best equipment. (Some people disingenuously equate super-shoes with doping, even though, unlike many chemicals, technical enhancements typically have no ill effects on their users.)

Part of the appeal of sports is that they show humans on an upward trajectory, becoming stronger, faster and fitter. This matters most in individual sports where competitors race against the clock, but it applies across the board. Technology has always contributed to this. Pristine modern football pitches enable a higher level of skill; bouncier tracks propel athletes along faster. But as the sports industry has sucked in more investment and prize pots have expanded, the incentives to find an edge in performance have grown, whether in kit, diet or game strategy. Sometimes advances have to be reined in—restrictions were placed on cricket-bat technology, for example, to prevent skewing the game in favour of batters; javelins were made less aerodynamic to save spectators from a spearing. But banning super-shoes would be both regressive and difficult to enforce. This is a genie that cannot be returned to its shoebox.

Swimming offers a cautionary tale. At the 2008 Olympics, world records were smashed by swimmers wearing full-body polyurethane suits manufactured by Speedo, which improved buoyancy. Many of the same arguments levelled against the Speedo suits have been heard again in the super-shoe debate. Swimming's governing body, FINA , caved in to the critics and banned the suits in 2010. For the next few years swimmers were unable to match the feats of Beijing. But as time passed and improvements were made elsewhere, new performers began to catch up. Now only one of the women's world records set in a Speedo suit still stands. Ms Assefa and Mr Kiptum are astonishing athletes and we should marvel at their feats, not what's on their feet. In the future, their records, too, will be surpassed by ever more impressive achievements. ■

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 16:23:03 GMT /content/5q6m793ub3mulrev40c9562smr1na5e2 https://www.economist.com/films/2023/11/03/how-to-be-a-better-boss When should Rishi Sunak call the next British election?

F or someone who values fiscal prudence, Rishi Sunak bears a strong resemblance to Charles Dickens's Wilkins Micawber. During his tenure as chancellor of the exchequer (and largely owing to the pandemic) public debt ballooned, from 84.5% of GDP to 96%. As prime minister, Mr Sunak's political strategy seems to be almost pure Micawberism—a hope that something will turn up. Whatever turns up insofar as the economy is concerned is unlikely to be good for the Tories.

The latest date that the next general election can be held is in January 2025. But campaigning over the Christmas holidays next year is unlikely to endear the government to voters. Two other options are seen as much more likely. One is to call an election in the autumn of 2024; another is to hold one on the same day as local elections due in early May. The conventional wisdom in Westminster holds that Mr Sunak will want to wait until the autumn, so that the economy has more time to recover and inflation more time to fall .

Yet the forecasts for the remaining 15 months of this Parliament do not suggest that there would be a big economic pay-off to delay. The annual inflation rate, an uncomfortably high 6.7% in September, is expected to fall sharply in the months ahead as the impact of 2022's surge in energy prices drops out of the figures. The Bank of England's median forecast for inflation by the second quarter of 2024—and a May election—is 3.7%; come the final quarter, it would have fallen only a bit more, to 3.4%.

And although the public may welcome lower inflation, they do not like the mechanism which is helping to deliver it: tighter monetary policy . On November 2nd the Bank of England held interest rates steady, at 5.25%, just as it did in its previous meeting, in September. But this pause followed 14 consecutive hikes. And because changes in interest rates take time to have an effect, the bulk of the pain from that tightening, the fastest in several decades, is yet to be felt by households.

Swati Dhingra, a member of the rate-setting monetary policy committee, argued in October that only 20-25% of the tightening since December 2021, when interest rates were just 0.1%, has been absorbed so far. According to UK Finance, a trade body, 1.6m fixed-rate mortgages in Britain are due to expire in 2024. For each month that the next general election is delayed an average of around 133,000 additional households will experience a nasty interest-rate increase. Mortgage brokers estimate that the typical remortgage will cost households £288 ($351) more each month than they are paying now.

The rise in interest rates will also gradually lead to higher unemployment. The bank expects unemployment to be 4.5% in the second quarter of next year, up from 4.3% now, and to reach 4.7% by the final quarter. In the 1960s Arthur Okun, an American economist, devised the “misery index”, which adds together the rate of inflation and the level of unemployment, to measure public unhappiness at the state of the economy. More recent research by economists indicates that people typically value low unemployment almost twice as much as they do lower price growth. Waiting a few months so that inflation is 0.3 percentage points lower and unemployment is 0.2 percentage points higher is unlikely to make voters much happier.

Mr Sunak faces a tough choice, in other words. Going for an early election when the Conservative Party is more than 20 percentage points behind Labour in the polls would seem foolhardy. But each month that he delays the inevitable, more mortgage-holders—a traditional bedrock of Tory support—will get clobbered by higher rates. Things eventually ended well for Mr Micawber, who was able to see out his days in the sunny, English-speaking climes of Australia. Mr Sunak is known to like California. ■

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 11:48:59 GMT /content/vcr4bioub4i432cncl6gu9s0nq8k87e2 https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/11/03/why-a-verdict-in-sam-bankman-frieds-trial-was-so-quick Sam Bankman-Fried’s downfall is complete

I T TOOK A jury just four hours to deliberate on the seven, complicated charges of financial fraud facing Sam Bankman-Fried , the founder of FTX , a cryptocurrency exchange. They had to parse what would make him guilty of defrauding his customers and his lenders; and of conspiring with others to commit securities fraud, commodities fraud and money-laundering. After 15 days of testimony they had clearly heard enough. They convicted him of each and every count. He faces a maximum sentence of 110 years in jail.

Only a year has elapsed since ftx imploded. In its heyday the exchange was one of the world's largest, with millions of customers and billions of dollars in customer funds. It was seen as the future of crypto—a high-tech offering from a brilliant wunderkind who wanted to play nice with regulators and usher in an era in which the industry went mainstream. But on November 2nd 2022 CoinDesk, a crypto news outlet, published a leaked balance-sheet. It showed that Alameda, ftx ’s sister hedge fund also founded by Mr Bankman-Fried, held few assets apart from a handful of illiquid tokens he had invented. Spooked customers began to pull holdings from the exchange. Within days it had become an all-out run and ftx had stopped meeting withdrawal requests. Customers still had $8bn deposited on the exchange. After frantically trying to raise funds, Mr Bankman-Fried placed ftx into bankruptcy.

Various accounts of what went wrong have emerged since. Many came from Mr Bankman-Fried himself, who spoke with dozens of journalists in the weeks following FTX ’s collapse. Michael Lewis, an author who was “embedded” with Mr Bankman-Fried for weeks before and after it failed, has published a book about him. Snippets have come from people tracing the movement of tokens on blockchains. The government revealed its theory of the case in several indictments. But little compares with the reams of evidence that were divulged during the trial by former FTX insiders, some of whom were testifying in co-operation with the government, having pleaded guilty to fraud already.

Some of the story remains the same regardless of the narrator. Mr Bankman-Fried was a gifted mathematician, who graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology ( MIT ) in 2014 before taking a job as a trader at Jane Street Capital, a prestigious quantitative hedge fund. In 2017 he spied an opportunity to set up a fund that would take advantage of arbitrage opportunities in illiquid and fragmented cryptocurrency markets, which were, per his telling, “a thousand times as large” than those in traditional markets. He enlisted an old friend, Gary Wang, a coder he had met at maths camp, to help set up the fund, which he named Alameda Research. He hired Nishad Singh, another coder and friend, as well as Caroline Ellison, a trader he had met at Jane Street.

The tales begin to diverge from here. Ms Ellison, Mr Singh and Mr Wang all testified for the prosecution in the trial, speaking for hours about their version of the dizzying ascent and devastating collapse of Alameda and FTX .

The way Ms Ellison described it, Mr Bankman-Fried was frustrated by how little capital Alameda had. He was “very ambitious”. In 2019 he described FTX to Ms Ellison as “a good source of capital” for Alameda. Mr Wang testified that he wrote code that allowed Alameda to have a negative balance on FTX —to withdraw more than the value of its assets—as early as 2019. Alameda was given a line of credit, which started small but ultimately increased to $65bn. Mr Wang also said that he overheard a conversation in which a trader asked Mr Bankman-Fried if Alameda could keep withdrawing money from the firm. Fine, as long as withdrawals were less than FTX ’s trading revenues, came the reply. But less than a year after FTX was founded, when Mr Wang went to check its balance, Alameda had already withdrawn more than that.

Customer deposits are supposed to be sacred, able to be withdrawn at any time. But even months in, Alameda already seemed to be borrowing that money for its own purposes. Mr Bankman-Fried said that he set up FTX because he thought he could create an excellent futures exchange, rather than to satisfy a desire for capital. He explained away Alameda's privileges by saying he was only vaguely aware of them and had thought them necessary for FTX to function, especially in the early days when Alameda was by far the largest marketmaker on the exchange and there were sometimes bugs in the code that liquidated accounts. If Alameda was liquidated it would be catastrophic. Mr Bankman-Fried did not want this to happen, and he wanted the fund to be able to make markets.

This might have been an excuse a jury could have swallowed, even though, by last year, Alameda was just one of perhaps 15 major marketmakers on the exchange and the others did not get such benefits. But two lines of argument undermined it. The first is how the privileges were used. The second is how Mr Bankman-Fried described FTX and its relationship with Alameda.

Start with how Alameda used its privileges. Ms Ellison, whom Mr Bankman-Fried made co-chief executive of Alameda in 2021, when he stepped back to focus on his exchange, described the many times Alameda withdrew serious money from FTX . The first was when Mr Bankman-Fried wanted to buy a stake in FTX that Binance, a rival, owned. His relationship with the boss of Binance had soured and he was worried that regulators would not like its involvement. It was going to cost around $1bn to buy the stake, around the same amount of capital FTX was raising from investors. Ms Ellison said she told Mr Bankman-Fried “we don't really have the money” and that Alameda would need to borrow from FTX to make the purchase. He told her to do it—“that's okay, I think this is really important.”

Borrowing to cover venture investments that were illiquid made the hole deeper. By late 2021 Mr Bankman-Fried nevertheless wanted to make another $3bn of investments. He asked Ms Ellison what would happen if the value of stocks, cryptocurrencies and venture investments collapsed and, in addition, FTX and Alameda struggled to secure more funds. She calculated that it would be “almost impossible” for Alameda to pay back what they had borrowed. Still, he told her to go ahead with the investment. By the next summer, Ms Ellison had been proved right.

Mr Singh testified at length about “excessive” spending. Around $1bn went on marketing, including Super Bowl adverts and endorsements from the likes of Tom Brady, an American footballer—around the same as FTX ’s revenue in 2021. By the end, Alameda had made some $5bn in “related party” loans to Mr Bankman-Fried, Mr Wang and Mr Singh to cover venture investments, property purchases and personal expenses. At one point, under cross examination, Danielle Sassoon, the prosecutor, asked Mr Bankman-Fried to confirm whether he had flown to the Super Bowl on a private jet. When he said he was unsure, she pulled up a picture of him reclining in the plush interior of a small plane. “It was a chartered plane, at least,” he shrugged.

The prosecution often used Mr Bankman-Fried's own words against him. Ms Sassoon would get Mr Bankman-Fried to say whether he agreed with a statement, such as whether he was walled off from trading decisions at Alameda. Mr Bankman-Fried would obfuscate, but eventually she would pin him down. “I was not generally making trading decisions, but I was not walled off from information from Alameda,” he admitted. Ms Sassoon then played a clip of him claiming he “was totally walled off from trading at Alameda”. Ms Sassoon did this over and over. Like an archer she would string her bow by asking a question, then release the arrow of evidence to prove a lie. At one point his lawyer slowed the pace of evidence by interrupting and asking if a document was being offered for its truth. “Your honour, it's the defendant's own statements,” the prosecutor said. “No, it's not being offered for its truth.”

Perhaps the most convincing moments of the trial were emotional ones. Ms Ellison was in tears as she told how, in the week of FTX ’s collapse, “one of the feelings I had was an overwhelming feeling of relief.” Meanwhile, Mr Singh described a cinematic confrontation with Mr Bankman-Fried in September last year, when he realised how big “the hole” was. He described pacing the balcony of the penthouse (cost: $35m) where many FTX employees lived, expressing horror that some $13bn of customer money had been borrowed, much of which could not be paid back. In response, Mr Bankman-Fried, lounging on a deck chair, replied: “Right, that. We are a little short on deliverables.”

As customers rushed to take their money in the week that FTX collapsed, employees resigned en masse. Adam Yedidia, one of Mr Bankman-Fried's friends and employees, who has not been charged with any crimes and appears to have been in the dark, texted him: “I love you Sam, I am not going anywhere.” Days later, when he had learned the reality of what had gone on, he was gone. Many of those who were close to Mr Bankman-Fried and knew what was going on foresaw how this would end—those who did not were horrified when they found out. So was the jury. ■

J UST WEEKS after the ninth anniversary of my father receiving a life sentence, I married the love of my life. We held our wedding ceremony at the local mosque, knowing that my father, Ilham Tohti, a Uyghur scholar, could not be by my side. He has not even met my new husband.

I look to my father for guidance every day, even though it has been years since we were last permitted to speak. I feel his presence as I carry the torch of his advocacy for marginalised people in China and around the world. In my homeland, the Uyghur Region (which the Chinese government calls Xinjiang ), Uyghurs like me and other Turkic and Muslim-majority peoples are being subjected to an ethnic-cleansing campaign that includes mass detention, abuse and systematic state-sponsored forced labour.

My father dedicated his life to speaking up for justice, advocating for a world in which all people can express their beliefs, be free to follow the traditions of their own culture and be respected as equals. He was arrested by the Chinese government in January 2014 on charges of inciting separatism. Eight months later, without a fair trial, he was sentenced to life in prison and put in solitary confinement. All for standing against the very oppression that Uyghurs are experiencing today.

In September I heard that Rahile Dawut, a renowned Uyghur anthropologist, had also been sentenced to life in prison. I am deeply saddened that her daughter, Akida Pulat, had to find out about her mother's sentencing on the news, just as I did over nine years ago. The kind of draconian treatment that my father received is still being meted out to intellectuals or anyone who thinks differently, behaves differently or has a different culture and ethnic identity from the Han Chinese.

My hope is that governments will take action to address the human-rights crisis facing the Uyghur people. There have been some positive signs: in 2021 President Joe Biden signed the Uyghur Forced Labour Prevention Act ( UFLPA ), which prohibits goods made in whole or in part in the Uyghur Region from entering America. The UFLPA is the strongest piece of legislation globally to address corporate complicity in Uyghur forced labour. Since the law's enforcement began, more than 5,000 shipments, with a value of $1.8bn, have been detained. More than half of these have been denied entry to America.

Since the UFLPA came into force, China has grown much less cotton in the Uyghur Region. China is the world's biggest grower and the key processor of the crop—accounting for over 20% of global production by volume—but its output looks set to fall by more than 10% this year. The Uyghur Region's share of the global market for polysilicon, a key component in solar panels, has also fallen, from 45% to 35% in just a couple of years.

However, this law is not enough. Companies need to ensure that no part of their supply chain is linked directly or indirectly to Uyghur forced labour. Governments should address gaps in corporate accountability by adopting legally binding measures that require human-rights due diligence to identify, prevent and remedy abuses in their supply chains and hold companies legally accountable for complicity. Governments should also impose sanctions on individuals and entities that are responsible for, or benefit from, forced labour. They should adopt laws similar to the UFLPA to ensure their markets are not dumping grounds for goods forcibly made by Uyghurs. No Uyghur in the diaspora should be left wondering like me: did my imprisoned father or cousin or uncle make this shirt?

In the years since my father's arrest, I have visited prisons and read, watched and listened to whatever I could to try to understand the experience of those locked up. I wonder: what is my father doing in one of those dark cells? Does he have enough to eat? Is there even a toilet in his cell? Is he allowed to read? Is he forced to work day and night making garments or packaging red dates? And the question that scares me the most: is he even alive? I still don't have any answers. The Chinese government has denied my father family visits since 2017.

Despite the positive impact of the UFLPA , many Uyghurs are still suffering, their freedoms restricted. The Chinese government falsely labels its campaign against them, including forced relocation and mass internment, as “poverty alleviation” and an effort to stamp out “separatism, terrorism and extremism”. For my father, as an economist, teacher and author, poverty alleviation was an academic bedrock. He believes that economic growth requires equal access to decent education and jobs, and that growth must not come at the expense of freedom—of culture, worship or expression.

His main point was simple: if the Chinese government would follow its own laws, which guarantee extensive autonomy to regions where the majority of the population was historically not Han Chinese, the Uyghurs would have the opportunity to share in growth—to the ultimate benefit of the entire country. Unfortunately, the Chinese government is not abiding by its own laws. Instead, it decided my father's work was a threat to the regime. Dr Dawut's life sentence in September for “endangering state security” is a reminder that although the plight of Uyghurs may have faded from headlines, China's oppression of my people continues unrelentingly.

What will it take for governments, corporations, investors and individuals to decide that our suffering has gone on long enough, and that the wrongful imprisonment must end? As the daughter of Ilham Tohti, I live in fear at all times. I fear that many more innocent Uyghurs will, like my father, be left forgotten in dark cells. I fear that one day no one will remember Ilham Tohti. ■

Jewher Ilham is the Forced Labour Project Co-ordinator at the Worker Rights Consortium and a spokesperson for the Coalition to End Forced Labour in the Uyghur Region.
